Item Creation Process: Crafting · Design · Fabrication · Materials · Production
Design Types: Tools · Clothing and Jewelery · Containers


The first step in fabricating a new object is to select a known design from the character's catalogue of known designs. This catalogue is sorted, first, by type of object (tools, Clothing and Jewelery, and containers). From there, these categories further subdivide, akin to file folders, until the player has access to the type of object they wish to create.

Once the Design has been selected, it opens the Design dialogue, which displays the object to be created and its stats, a list of the component materials required (with spaces into which they can be dropped), and the character's own inventory.

Design Types

Tools

Tools are used by holding them. An item crafted as a tool generally has no effect if not carried in hand, or has an effect that was started while it was carried in hand.

Clothing and Jewelery

Clothing and Jewelery are things which are used by wearing them. Clothing and Jewelery which is held in hand or placed in storage has no effect.

Containers

Unlike the other two types, which are defined by how they are placed for use, Containers are defined by the fact their sole use is storage. Sometimes worn, sometimes carried, sometimes left in a place for safekeeping- the location is less important than the purpose.

Some Clothing, Jewelery, and Tools contain storage space within them. Those objects are created by their primary purpose, with the Container aspect being added as a modification.

Locks

Making New Designs

When the design catalogue is open to a specific type of item (axes, rings, bags, etc) a button will appear at the bottom of the dialogue which reads "Create New Design." If this is pressed the New Design dialogue opens.

Making a design is somewhat like building a spell. The character determines what materials, of those they have available to them, they wish to use. Between the materials and the basic form the object will have certain characteristics. From there, the player determines what additional alterations they wish to make to the final product. These changes modify the difficulty of using the design. The materials and effects will strongly determine the appearance of the created item, though the details of the item's appearence can be varied somewhat by those who wish to do so.


Note, the base difficulty for designs vary depending on the ingredients and the products. It is far easier for a meal to be made to poison those who eat it when made from rancid meat than it is to ensure it does not poison it's consumers. Similarly, it's easier to make a meal made of rancid meat poisonous than it is a meal made of fresh ingredients. Conversley, making a meal that bolsters the consumer from spoiled components will generally provide penalties which will require a Cook of truely epic skill.

General Rules

Mixed Media

Items which are composed of substances from two different skills, such as studded leather armor (Blacksmith for the studs and Tailor for the general armor) or axes (Carpenter for the shaft and Blacksmith for the head) generally have pieces assembled and the final product is then created using its own recipe. This final recipe may be a part of the skill more appropriate to its final creation (Tailors make studded leather) or may be equally available to multiple skills (either Carpenters or Blacksmiths may assemble the head and handle into an axe).

Size

The base size, in slots, of an item is equal to the space occupied by the components. Components which are particularly small are generally ignored when they are incorporated into "normal sized" objects.

Durability

Each additional point of durability increases the difficulty by one tenth the higher of the substance's Malleability, Fragility, or Viscosity.
